newsitem.title: USA: Lower rates lure corp issuers into U.S. debt arena.
newsitem.headline: Lower rates lure corp issuers into U.S. debt arena.

text.p: Attractive U.S. interest rates are luring corporate bond issuers into the primary arena as close to $4.0 billion is already slated to hit the market this week, dealers said.
Triggering the onslaught of corporate supply is the drop in interest rates following weaker-than-expected U.S. economic data last week.
Players said the reports confirmed that further tightening by the Federal Reserve is not imminent, therefore creating a window of opportunity for isuers to finance debt at lower levels.

"We're going to see a busy week," said one syndicate player. "Rates have improved tremendously ... we should see those stil contemplating issuance come off the sidelines to take advantage of cheaper financing."
U.S. Treasury yields have come down considerably in the last few weeks. The 30-year Treasury bond closed at a yield of 7.03 percent back on May 28th, but has since fallen to 6.71 percent.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the policysetting arm of the Fed, is scheduled to meet on July 1 and 2 to vote on U.S. monetary policy.
Old Republic International is expected to sell $115 million in Aa2/AA-minus rated 10-year debt via Lehman Brothers, players said.
Among global issuers, American Express is slated to tap the market with a $500 million A1/A-plus rated seven-year debt offering via Lehman Brothers, sources said.
Another $1.0 billion in AAA rated 10-year gobal debt is expected to come from Bayerische Landesbank via JP Morgan Securities and Merrill Lynch, players said.
Turning to the high-yield sector, about $1.7 billion in new debt is expected this week, sources said.
